newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: Former Tradenz ceo Christie leaves ANZ Bank - paper.
newsitem.headline: Former Tradenz ceo Christie leaves ANZ Bank - paper.

text.p: High-profile executive Rick Christie has quit as head of ANZ Bank's international banking group in a surprise move after just six months in the job, Wellington's Evening Post newspaper reported on Friday.
Christie, 55, previously chief executive of trade body Tradenz for six years, was head-hunted to ANZ Bank by its New Zealand managing director, Steve Jones. Jones later left the bank.
Christie said part of the reason he resigned was the almost complete change in senior management at ANZ.
Alister Maitland, the Melbourne-based executive director of international banking, had retired, Jones had left, and Australian chief executive officer Don Mercer was to leave next year, he said.
"My feeling is that the original vision that we shared when I came on board has fundamentally changed and, because of that, I have decided to strike out and do something else," he said.
When Christie joined ANZ, Jones hailed his appointment, saying it would add more "management push power" to its international banking business in New Zealand.

The bank had been looking for someone who understood what firms needed from their bank. A person with these skills, such as Christie, would complement ANZ's range of financial capabilities, Jones said.
"We realised that there was a person in the country who was uniquely placed to do that. The problem was he was chief executive of Tradenz," he said.
Despite his early departure, Christie said there was no acrimony and he left the bank on good terms three weeks ago.
It was his decision to leave, he said.
Christie said he was pursuing a number of job opportunities, including some directorships, and had recently turned down a position overseas.
